As you can see on the screenshot below:
![screen shot 2015-06-29 at 08 07 54](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/34704/8398733/0b060ac2-1e36-11e5-95a5-ef1c396f1a06.png)

Atom was started with `atom --safe <directoryname>`.
OS X 10.10.3, Atom 1.0.
Other folders work well.

data.title: Does not follow file after an "atomic save" by other text editors
data.body:
For a given file open in atom, after an "atomic save" is perfomed by a different application, atom will no longer have the "real" file open, instead it will have the old version of the file left open. When the tab is closed, the message will read 

> 'README.md~' has changes, do you want to save them? Your changes will be lost if you close this item without saving

And then the user has to go back to their tree view and re-open the original file.

For reference, an atomic save is one where, instead of simply rewriting the contents of a file, the original file is moved (like `README.md` -> `README.md~`), and then a new file is written in the original location. Applications such as vim, gedit and qtcreator do this when saving files. In my case, with qtcreator, there is no option to turn this behaviour off. It's even [considered a bug to some Sublime Text users](https://github.com/SublimeTextIssues/Core/issues/379).

Currently on Windows, Atom 1.0.0. Occurs in safe mode.

This bug can probably be addressed in `node-pathwatcher`.

data.title: Could not resolve 'jshint' to a package path: Atom 1.0.0
data.body:
#### Steps:

This is running in safe mode, with developer console open.
1. Settings > Install, search for 'linter'
2. click Themes, then click Packages (needed to actually show search results ??)
3. Find jshint (1.3.8) and click Install.

After a pause, console shows:

```
C:\Users\[me]\AppData\Local\atom\app-1.0.0\resources\app.asar\src\package-manager.js:377
Could not resolve 'jshint' to a package path
```

Ditto with `atom-jshint` (2.0.0), `wl-jshinter` (0.3.3), `optional-jshint` (3.0.0).
#### Atom version: 1.0.0
#### OS: Windows 7

Issue search found https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/4721 but this seems to relate to an earlier version of Atom. Didn't find anything related to 1.0.
(Correction - possibly related to https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/7335)

data.title: A missing detail about code folding
data.body:
The three assumptions below explain what is broken about code folding in Atom.
1. The caret is visible.
2. User folds the code with a key binding.
3. The caret is now offscreen.

Step three is where the problem lies.

If the caret is offscreen before the user folded the code, it's good to leave the caret where it ends up.

Otherwise, it makes more sense to move the caret into view. This means scrolling the page until the caret is in the middle of the screen.

Thoughts? :smile:

data.title: Undo of actions taken by package results in corrupted display of buffer
data.body:
I wrote a package: https://atom.io/packages/joe-keybinds (github: https://github.com/iarna/atom-joe) and when I use the move operation it provides (https://github.com/iarna/atom-joe/blob/master/lib/joe.coffee#L56-L67) and then undo it with Cmd-Z, the resulting _display_ of the buffer is corrupted. I can tell that the underlying buffer is fine because saving and reloading shows the undo occurred correctly. The display corruption shows duplicated lines where there are none, and things like what constitutes the end of the line no longer match the display.

The move operation uses `transact` to combine of the pieces of the move operation into a single undoable chunk.

data.title: Move cursor when transposing characters
data.body:
One subtle but unexpectedly cool feature of Emacs's "transpose" functionality is that it moves the cursor.  As of 1.0.0, Atom doesn't do that.  But it allows me to move a character by using transpose.

If you position the cursor to the right of x and then invoke transpose multiple times, you get the following.  (First line shows the starting point, second line shows after the first transpose, third line after the second transpose, and so on.)

```
aXbcde
abXcde
abcXde
abcdXe
```

Note that the user has just used <kbd>Ctrl-T</kbd>, no other key was pressed.  In Atom, I have to <kbd>Ctrl-T</kbd>, <kbd>right</kbd>, <kbd>Ctrl-T</kbd>, <kbd>right</kbd>, ... to achieve the same effect.

This is related to https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/5410 which also asks to improve the behavior of transpose.

data.title: Ignored file patterns vs. searching, fuzzy finder, opening from tree view
data.body:
Currently, opening files through the fuzzy finder or searching in project files can take a long time and make Atom slowish when you have folders like `node_modules` and `bower_components` in your project which can get quite large.

A solution is to add these folders to Atom's list of Ignored names. However, this causes them to disappear from the tree view as well, making it impossible to look in them if needed, unless you remove them from the ignored names again.

Needless to say going back and forth like this is a bit of a hassle, especially when working on different projects where you need frequent access to `node_modules` and others where you don't. I find myself adding and removing `node_modules` from the ignore list at least two or three times a day.

Is there a way to support this use case? Some idea's that come to mind:
- Exclude files and folders listed in .gitignore from the fuzzy finder / search in files? That way I don't have to add `node_modules` to Atom's ignore list, it will still be accessible in tree view (greyed out), yet it won't slow Atom by searching in those folders.
- Have a separate ignore list for the search / fuzzy file opener? That way `node_modules` can be visible in Atom, but search and fuzzy file opener will be able to ignore it.
- A toggle option to "view ignored files/folders"? They will be displayed in the tree view (greyed out) when toggled, but all other functionality remains the same (e.g. they are not included in the search).

data.title: Incorrect Arch Linux installation instructions
data.body:
Hi, 

I know I could go about this with a pull request but it's only a single word addition to the Linux.md file so I felt a developer with write permissions to the GitHub repo could just read this and make the change. At the moment the Linux.md file reads this in its Arch Linux dependency installation instructions:

> - `sudo pacman -S gconf base-devel git nodejs libgnome-keyring python2`
> - `export PYTHON=/usr/bin/python2` before building Atom.

The amendment I propose is to add `npm` after `nodejs` in the first of these lines, in accordance with the [official Nodejs Wiki installation instructions](https://github.com/joyent/node/wiki/Installing-Node.js-via-package-manager#arch-linux). I have tested this on a 32 bit Manjaro Linux Virtual Machine (which is as close to Arch that I can effectively work with-- Arch is over my head): without `npm` in this line, later during the actual build `script/build` generated errors stating that it could not find npm. 

I hope this helps,
Brenton

data.title: OSX: `atom` shell command always moves one desktop to the left
data.body:
``` sh
atom ~/.bashrc
```

Instead of focusing on the Atom editor (as expected), it always focuses on the desktop to the left of the selected desktop (even if Atom isn't on that desktop).

Has anyone else experienced this? It's quite annoying having to four-finger-swipe to the desktop Atom is on every time I open a file thru the terminal.

**EDIT:** If the file is not yet open, the Atom editor **will** be focused. But if it's already open, I'm moved a desktop to the left and then nothing happens.

**EDIT 2:** I'm on OSX 10.10.2

data.title: CentOS 7.1.1503 x64 MainUI is not Unicode
data.body: ![20150628212038](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11887000/8396513/976ddf0e-1ddb-11e5-9ddc-b627a10144cc.png)

data.title: Hide search pane
data.body:
I've searched the ten first pages of issues with the term "search" but couldn't find this issue.

I can toggle search by pressing CTRL+F, as it should. However, I can't find any way to close that pane. Maybe an <kbd>x</kbd> would be nice or at least a notion of the search pane in `View`?

It doesn't seem like a good idea to be able to toggle it with CTRL+F. That one should only be used for opening the search box. That way you can't accidentally close the search box when it's already open.

data.title: Deb install error on 64-bit Ubuntu 14.04 LTS
data.body:
> cannot copy extracted data for './usr/share/doc/atom/copyright' to '/usr/share/doc/atom/copyright.dpkg-new': unexpected end of file or stream

Downloaded a couple of times from github/atom.io but doesn't seem to be a corrupt file.

sudo apt-get clean didn't help.

UPDATE: Successfully installed using webupd8team PPA. Deb issue unresolved.

data.title: Choosing installation directory and other installation options
data.body:
So far I really like Atom 1.0 - it's got a long way to go, but it will get there. We needed an editor like this.

Anyway: the only thing bothering me was how quickly it installed itself (Windows 8.1, 64 bit). Even though that might sound like a _good_¨thing, it isn't. When I double-click the installer I get no options, no information whatsoever. Only a screen "Atom is installing and will launch when ready." For some people this might be the best approach, but for a whole lot of others it isn't.

Some options would be great. I am thinking: file association, installation directory, packages to include with installation (I for one don't need all packages that are included on default install) and so on. I could understand that file association and package control aren't included (though I'd really like that) but why not the ability to choose your own installation directory?

data.body:

Some options would be great. I am thinking: file association, installation directory, packages to include with installation (I for one don't need all packages that are included on default install) and so on. I could understand that file association and package control aren't included (though I'd really like that) but why not the ability to choose your own installation directory?

data.title: Selects are rendered unusable with HiDPI scaling
data.body:
#### Summary

The theme chooser does not appear to work on my system. I cannot select a theme.
#### Setup

Ubuntu 15.04 with atom 1.0.0 amd64 freshly installed from .deb package. 
#### Observed behaviour

Themes show up in the list of Core Themes and Installed Themes. However, when I click the drop-down selectors for UI Theme and Syntax Theme, they only show an empty white box, with 'One Dark' remaining selected.
![screenshot from 2015-06-28 09 53 40](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7723154/8395764/8a14958c-1d7c-11e5-91b7-4b53dd41e2b0.png)
#### Expected behaviour

I would have expected the names of installed themes to appear in the drop-down box so that I could select another theme.
#### Notes

Not sure if this is relevant or a separate bug, but searching for themes using the 'filter themes by name' box does not return any themes.

data.title: instructions how to make sysctl permissions permenent in linux build manual wrong
data.body:
Document in question: [docs/build-instructions/linux.md](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/docs/build-instructions/linux.md)

Currently:   `echo 32768 | sudo tee -a /proc/sys/fs/inotify/max_user_watches`

I fail to see how writing to /proc would make settings any more permanent than just sysctl'ing them.

I believe it is meant to be:
`echo fs.inotify.max_user_watches=32768 | sudo tee -a /etc/sysctl.d/local.conf`

data.title: Atom 1.0 does not work on Ubuntu 14.04
data.body:
I am trying to install Atom 1.0 on my Ubuntu 14.04 using [atom-amd64.deb](https://github.com/atom/atom/releases/download/v1.0.0/atom-amd64.deb) or `sudo add-apt-repository ppa:webupd8team/atom`. However, an error happened when I start atom (see the snapshot) and it cannot open any files.

![error](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3446306/8395182/9e06233c-1d93-11e5-97e7-b310ce0b31a1.png)

Then I removed this package with `apm remove recent-files`, but the editor still cannot work.

My Node.js environment is:

``` shell
$ node -v
v0.12.5
$ npm -v
2.11.2
```

data.title: Programmer's Dvorak Single Quote in Keybindings
data.body: When using Programmer's Dvorak on Linux the handler for keybinding events interprets the single quote as z. When inputting text the single quote is correctly interpreted. This is also the case for double quotes and Z. No other keys seem to be affected.

data.title: show file preview instead of opening in new tab
data.body:
With Sublime when we click from navigation on any file it is showing the content but not opening the tab yet, unless you modify the selected file or double click it...

Having every single file opening in new tab is annoying, sometimes you just want to see whats in there and go on...

data.title: allow to choose syntax without having to save file
data.body: With sublime i could create a new tab put some code and choose the syntax i wanted for that particular tab, with atom currently it is activating only when i save the file, and figures out correct syntax with file extension...

data.title: Atom packages not publish....
data.body:
Not sure this is the right place for this Issue (if yes, sorry). I'm really trying to publish a package to atom but I can not ..Does anyone know why or went through this same problem?
